'''Julius Bartels''' (August 17, 1899, [[Magdeburg]] – March 6, 1964) was a [[Germany|German]] [[geophysicist]] and [[statistician]] who made notable contributions to the physics of the [[Sun]] and [[Moon]]; to [[geomagnetism]] and [[meteorology]]; and to the physics of the [[ionosphere]]. He also made fundamental contributions to statistical methods for geophysics. Bartels was the first President of the [[International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy]]. With [[Sydney Chapman (astronomer)|Sydney Chapman]], he wrote the influential book ''[[List of important publications in geology#Geomagnetism|Geomagnetism]]''.

==Life and career==
Bartels was awarded his [[Ph.D.]] from [[Georg August University of Göttingen|Göttingen]] in 1923, then worked at the [[Potsdam]] magnetic observatory as a post-doctorate. In 1928 he was named [[professor]] at [[Eberswalde]], teaching [[meteorology]]. He became full professor at [[Humboldt University of Berlin|Berlin University]] in 1936, and director of the Potsdam Geophysical Institute. From 1931 until the second year of [[World War II]] he was also a research associate at the [[Carnegie Institution of Washington]]. He collaborated with [[Sydney Chapman (astronomer)|Sydney Chapman]] to publish the two-volume work ''Geomagnetism'', a definitive reference on geophysics.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.egu.eu/awards-medals/awards-and-medals/award/portrait-julius-bartels.html |title=Awards & Medals: Julius Bartels |author=[[European Geosciences Union]] |accessdate=September 2011}}</ref>

Following the war in 1946 he became professor in Göttingen. He was also a director at the [[Max Planck Society|Max Planck Institute]] for Physics of the [[Stratosphere]] (today [[Max Planck Institute for Solar System Research]]) between 1955 and 1964. When 1958 [[ICSU]] created the [[Committee on Space Research]] (''COSPAR''). Bartels became chairman of the (West-)German branch. From 1954 until 1957 he served as first President of the [[International Association of Geomagnetism and Aeronomy|IAGA]]. Between 1960 and 1963 he was vice-president of the [[International Union of Geodesy and Geophysics|IUGG]].<ref>A memorial note was published in Meteorlogische Rundschau 1964 by Wilfried Schröder.</ref>

==Research==

Among his contributions was the development of the [[K-index|Kp-index]], and he suggested the existence of "M-regions" on the [[Sun]] that resulted in geomagnetic activity. These [[coronal holes]] were later confirmed by the [[Skylab]] mission. Finally he also helped initiate the [[International Geophysical Year]], which took place in 1957/8.

The [[Bartels' Rotation Number]] of the Sun based on a regular 27 day cycle is named after him.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bartels |first1=J. |year=1934 |title=Twenty-Seven Day Recurrences in Terrestrial-Magnetic and Solar Activity, 1923 1933 |journal=[[Terrestrial Magnetism and Atmospheric Electricity]] |volume=39 |issue=3 |pages=201–202a |doi=10.1029/TE039i003p00201 |bibcode = 1934TeMAE..39..201B }}</ref> It is similar to the [[Carrington rotation]] which is based on 27.2753 days.

==Awards and honors==
* Posthumously awarded the [[William Bowie Medal]] of the [[American Geophysical Union]].
* The ''Julius Bartels Medal'', of the [[European Geosciences Union]] Division on Solar-Terrestrial Sciences, was named in his honor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.egu.eu/awards-medals/awards-and-medals/award/julius-bartels.html |title=Awards & Honors: Julius Bartels Medal |author=[[European Geosciences Union]] |accessdate=September 2011}}</ref>
* The crater [[Bartels (crater)|Bartels]] on the [[Moon]] is named after him.
*[[The Chree Medal and Prize]] in 1953
